prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: AS1063
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map the lensed red submm source in continuum and in the [CII] line at 267.4GHz (z=6.107). Detect the CO(3-2) line in the cluster galaxies at 256.9 GHz (z=0.346).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
1. Continuum in the red laboca source ------------------------------------- Our primary goal is to map at 1'' resolution the LABOCA source which has a flux of 7mJy at 870um.
With an rms of 0.1mJy at 267GHz we will detect the source at S/N>10 even if it is resolved into mutliple sources.
According to the Fig.1 we will also detect any lensed dusty star forming galaxy with LFIR>10^11Lsol when it is magnified by a factor x3.
2. [CII] line in the red laboca source ----------------------------------------- We also want to detect the [CII] line in the LABOCA source assumed at z=6.107, magnified by a factor x10 and with LFIR=5-15x10^11 Lsol (Boone et al 2013). The line is redshifted to 267.39 GHz (baseband 3). We will obtain an rms of 1mJy in 80km/s channels. We should therefore be able to detect an unlensed line luminosity of 5x10^8 Lsol with a S/N=5 (assuming a line width of 200km/s). If we assume LCII/LFIR=1e-3, this implies that we will detect the source with a S/N>5.
3. Continuum in the HST source magnified by x30 ----------------------------------------------- We will obtain an rms of 3.3 microJy in the source plane, and from Fig.1 (take the 3 sigma detection limit, Lfir=10^11 divided by 10 because the figure assumes a magnification x3) we will detect LFIR~10^10 ie SFR=1.7 Msol/yr with S/N=3. Balestra et al 2013 predict SFR>6, so we should detect the source at high S/N.
4. CO(3-2) in the cluster galaxies --------------------------------- The cluster is at z=0.346 so that the CO(3-2) line in the cluster galaxies is at 256.887GHz, which will fall in the baseband 2. With rms=1mJy in 80km/s channels we will be able to detect CO luminosities of 7.4x10^6 K km/s. Assuming a co-to-H2 conversion factor, alpha=4.7 this is equivalent to gas masses >5x10^7 Msol (unresolved). The galaxies will be resolved in ~10 beams so we will detect and resolve the galaxies with total molecular gas masses>5x10^8 Msol.

Our primary goal is to detect the continuum, that is why we select the broadest band with the lowest spectral resolution in 3 subbands.
In the third subband however, we would like to detect CII at z=6.1. The line may be as narrow as 50km/s. For this subband we therefore require a spectral resolution of 9km/s.

This is a detection project we do not want to resolve out flux in the sources which should typically be 1'' in size.
There is no large scale to image in this project.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: MS2137
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map the lensed red submm sources in continuum. Detect the CO(3-2) line in the cluster galaxies at 263.363 GHz (z=0.313).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
1. Continuum in the red laboca source ------------------------------------- Our primary goal is to map at 1'' resolution the LABOCA source which has a continuum flux of 7mJy at 870um.
With an rms of 0.1mJy at 263GHz over the 7.5GHz total band we will detect it at S/N>10 even if it is resolved into mutliple sources.
According to the Fig.1 we will also detect any lensed dusty star forming galaxy with LFIR>10^11Lsol when it is magnified by a factor x3.
2. CO(3-2) in the cluster galaxies --------------------------------- The cluster is at z=0.313 so that the CO(3-2) line in the cluster galaxies is at 263.363GHz, which will fall in the baseband 3. With rms=1mJy in 80km/s channels we will be able to detect CO luminosities of 7.4x10^6 K km/s. Assuming a co-to-H2 conversion factor alpha=4.7, this is equivalent to gas masses >5x10^7 Msol (unresolved). The galaxies will be resolved in ~10 beams so we will detect and resolve the galaxies with total molecular gas masses>5x10^8 Msol.
Our primary goal is to detect the continuum, that is why we select the broadest band with the lowest spectral resolution in all subbands.

This is a detection project we do not want to resolve out flux in the sources which should typically be 1'' in size.
There is no large scale to image in this project.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: A2744
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map the lensed red submm sources in continuum. Detect the CO(3-2) line in the cluster galaxies at 264.694 GHz (z=0.3064).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
1. Continuum in the red laboca source ------------------------------------- Our primary goal is to map at 1'' resolution the LABOCA source which has a flux of 12mJy at 870um.
With an rms of 0.1mJy at 263GHz we will detect the source at S/N>10 even if it is resolved into mutliple sources.
According to the Fig.1 we will also detect any lensed dusty star forming galaxy with LFIR>10^11Lsol when it is magnified by a factor x3.
2. CO(3-2) in the cluster galaxies --------------------------------- The cluster is at z=0.3064 so that the CO(3-2) line in the cluster galaxies is at 264.694 GHz, which will fall in the baseband 3. With rms=1mJy in 80km/s channels we will be able to detect CO luminosities of 7.4x10^6 K km/s. Assuming co-to-H2 conversion factor alpha=4.7 this is equivalent to gas masses >5x10^7 Msol (unresolved). The galaxies will be resolved in ~10 beams so we will detect and resolve the galaxies with total molecular gas masses>5x10^8 Msol.
Our primary goal is to detect the continuum, that is why we select the broadest band with the lowest spectral resolution in all subbands.

This is a detection project we do not want to resolve out flux in the sources which should typically be 1'' in size.
There is no large scale to image in this project.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: A2667
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map the lensed red submm source in continuum. Detect and resolve the CO(3-2) line in the cluster galaxies at 280.451 GHz (z=0.233). Detect and resolve the CO(5-4) line in the giant arc at 283.457 GHz (z=0.233).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
1. Continuum in the red laboca source ------------------------------------- Our primary goal is to map at 1'' resolution the LABOCA source which has a peak flux of 7mJy at 870um.
With an rms of 0.11mJy at 263GHz we will detect the source at S/N>10 even if it is resolved into mutliple sources.
According to the Fig.1 we will also detect any lensed dusty star forming galaxy with LFIR>10^11Lsol when it is magnified by a factor x3.
**Note that to compensate for the slightly higher frequency the rms is 10% higher than for the other mosaics, thus the sensitivity on the distant dusty galaxies will be exactly the same
2. CO(3-2) in the cluster galaxies --------------------------------- The cluster is at z=0.233 so that the CO(3-2) line in the cluster galaxies is at 280.451 GHz (band 7). We propose to adjust the frequency to have the line in the baseband 1. Thus we can have the CO(5-4) line from the giant arc in the baseband 2 (see below). With rms=1mJy in 80km/s channels we will be able to detect CO luminosities of 7.4x10^6 K km/s. Assuming co-to-H2 conversion factor alpha=4.7 this is equivalent to gas masses >5x10^7 Msol (unresolved). The galaxies will be resolved in ~10 beams so we will detect and resolve the galaxies with total molecular gas masses>5x10^8 Msol.
3. CO(5-4) in the giant arc. ---------------------------- The giant arc is at z=1.033 so that the CO(5-4) line is at 283.457 GHz. The arc is well detected in our Herschel maps, suggesting a gas rich galaxy similar to the giant arc in A521 at the same redshift in which we detected the CO(5-4) line with the IRAM-30m telesocpe. The peak flux of the line was at ~60mJy. With an rms of 1mJy in 80km/s channels we will detect and resolve (in ~10 beams) the lensed galaxy at S/N>5.

Our primary goal is to detect the continuum, that is why we select the broadest band with the lowest spectral resolution in subbands 1, 3 and 4.
In subband 2 however, we would like to detect CO(5-4) form the giant. The line may be as narrow as 50km/s. For this subband we therefore require a spectral resolution of 9km/s.

This is a detection project we do not want to resolve out flux in the sources which should typically be 1'' in size.
There is no large scale to image in this project.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to unveil the nature of very red submm sources discovered in four out of 10 Herschel Lensing Survey (HLS) clusters followed up at 870microns with LABOCA. Undetected in the Herschel bands, these sources may be the first submm selected galaxies with moderate intrinsic luminosities (LFIR<10^12 Lsol) at very high redshifts (z>5) or low luminosity cold dusty galaxies with Td<25K. Measuring their luminosities and redshifts will put important constraints on the density of normal dusty star forming galaxies beyond z=4 and on the fraction of dusty star formation occuring in cold galaxies at lower redshift.
Mapping at 1.1mm with a sensitivity of 0.1mJy will allow us to detect these sources with S/N>10 as well as any other lensed galaxy with an intrinsic LFIR>10^11 Lsol up to z=10, and enable us to unambiguously identify their counterparts, estimate their redshift, and constrain their FIR luminosity and dust temperature. The core of massive galaxy clusters are the site of many astrophysical processes, and the data would further serve a number of ancillary purposes that we discuss in the text.
Resubmission of 2013.1.01119.S which started in Cycle 2 but no data delivered to date.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: CODE: 2013.1.01119.S TITLE: Unveiling the nature of the reddest submm sources in lensing cluster fields PI: Frederic Boone, 2013.1.01119.S
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
